content.statement: pad-002-fontaine-classification is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Peripheral-Arterial-Disease that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding pad-002-fontaine-classification helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of pad-002-fontaine-classification include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of pad-002-fontaine-classification.

definitions_glossary.claudication_distance: Maximum walking distance before claudication pain forces patient to stop
definitions_glossary.rest_pain: Ischemic pain occurring at rest, typically in forefoot, worse at night, relieved by dependency
definitions_glossary.tissue_loss: Ulceration or gangrene due to arterial insufficiency
definitions_glossary.critical_limb_ischemia: Fontaine Stage III or IV, characterized by rest pain or tissue loss

rest_pain_characteristics: Worse at night (elevation reduces perfusion pressure)
Relieved by dependency (hanging leg over bed)
Patients often sleep in chair or with legs down
tissue_loss_patterns: Arterial ulcers: punched-out, painful, on pressure points

natural_history.claudication_progression: Only 15-20% progress to CLI over 5 years
natural_history.cli_limb_loss: 25% major amputation at 1 year without revascularization

definition.@value: Four-stage clinical classification of peripheral arterial disease severity based on symptoms

skos:related.skos:note: Alternative classification system commonly used in North America

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Enumerate the four Fontaine stages and their criteria
Distinguish between claudication and critical limb ischemia
Understand treatment implications of each stage
Recognize clinical features of rest pain
clinical_pearls: Most claudicants (Stage II) stay stable - they don't all progress to CLI
Rest pain is ominous - requires urgent vascular evaluation
Night pain relieved by hanging leg down = classic rest pain
Fontaine is used more in Europe; Rutherford more in North America
